did was we started to think about how can we think of releases being scoped to
the name space rather than being globally scoped as in scope to the tiller instance so what this means is
now when you do a helm install in a particular namespace not only is the
deployments and the application that you're deploying on there is deployed in that namespace but also the release
records the in this case what used to be the config map that tiller would store which is now a secret those release
objects are now stored in the same namespace as the release itself so now you can actually have multiple releases
with the same name in the cluster but they're scopes at the namespace level and there's no more koop system usage so
there's no more like cluster level access that you need to actually go and finagle in there so that was home 3

upgrade what it does is it's called a to a merge patch and what it does is it
takes the difference of your previous release the last time you did an install
or an upgrade and then it does the diff against what you're currently trying to install or upgrade from there and it
does not take into effect anything that's live in the cluster so if you do like a coop CTL edit on your resources
or live patching on that on like a zero-day exploit or whatever happens to be why you're doing a coop detail edit
that doesn't get applied and a lot of people obviously really want to have

is the three-way merge patch that coops ETL apply currently does and the server side apply which is kind of like
experimental feature of where you apply or you supply a bunch of manifests to
kubernetes itself and they do the actual dipping and they do the apply rather than what we currently do which is the
helm client has to pull down the manifests do the dipping and then tell kubernetes what should be the state so
that's what we like to do and the other thing is well about changing upgrade is
that we can't necessarily treat an individual resource inside of an
application the same as we treat another resource there are relationships between all the different resources that you
have inside of your application like for example if you update a config map or
you update a persistent volume or heavens forbid that you delete your
persistent volume a person's volume claim from there should that delete your entire persistent volume and all state
from your application I bet most people in here probably don't want to have their applications state deleted when
they do an upgrade so that's really what we have to do is that we have to have these discreet relationships between
these different resources inside of the cluster and how we want to treat the upgrade compared to just saying here's
